channel.title: swissbib data blog
channel.description: Recent content on swissbib data blog

item.title: Exploring More Complex Patterns with Artificial Neural Networks
item.author: swissbib-ub@unibas.ch (project swissbib)
item.description: Besides the availability of data, an additional reason why Machine Learning has become a popular topic has to do with publicly available code libraries that simplify the implementation of machines. One such library is TensorFlow, an open-source platform written by Google Brain. TensorFlow can be used for implementing Neural Networks. Since the end of 2019 a library called keras has been integrated on top of TensorFlow. This library makes the code implementation of Neural Networks even easier.

item.title: What Humans Learn about the Data from a Support Vector Machine
item.author: swissbib-ub@unibas.ch (project swissbib)
item.description: Machine Learning may look mystical, although it is based on the mathematical discipline of statistics. If the learning process is done with a fixed data set, Machine Learning can be structured into two distinct groups of tasks, supervised and unsupervised learning. In supervised learning, the artificial machine is trained with a set of training data with a target value, each. In the first blog article, the feature records and their associated target value have been introduced for the swissbib project at hand.

item.title: A Machine Learning Approach with Ensemble Methods
item.author: swissbib-ub@unibas.ch (project swissbib)
item.description: The notion of Machine Learning includes a wide group of statistical algorithms where a computer system learns on a set of training data and, after having completed its learning phase, uses its experience to generate predictions on new, unknown data. In the context of the capstone project of an advanced online training course at EPF Lausanne, a swissbib admirer takes the challenge to do Machine Learning with a set of library catalogue data in MARC 21 format.

item.title: Warum maschinelles Lernen im swissbib Projekt
item.author: swissbib-ub@unibas.ch (project swissbib)
item.description: Seit gefühlt zwei, drei Jahren lassen sich kaum mehr Artikel zum Thema Daten und Informationen finden, in denen nicht mindestens einmal Begriffe wie “Maschinelles Lernen”, “Künstliche Intelligenz” (KI) oder “Neuronale Netze” erwähnt und als das Erfolgsrezept für die Zukunft beschrieben werden. Sollte damit das, was wir in den letzten 12 Jahren gemacht haben, veraltet und nicht mehr relevant sein? Das swissbib Team ist ja nicht dafür bekannt, sich vor neuen Softwaretechnologien zu scheuen.

item.title: Why machine learning in the swissbib project
item.author: swissbib-ub@unibas.ch (project swissbib)
item.description: For what feels like two or three years now, it has been almost impossible to find articles on the subject of data and information in which terms such as “Machine Learning”, “Artificial Intelligence” (AI) or “Neural Networks” are not mentioned at least once and described as the recipe for success for the future. Should this mean that what we have been doing over the last 12 years is outdated and no longer relevant?
